newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian bonds close weaker after 10-year auction.
newsitem.headline: Canadian bonds close weaker after 10-year auction.

text.p: Canadian bonds closed weaker on Wednesday, falling in tandem with U.S. Treasuries as the auction of 10-year bonds in both countries weighed on markets, analysts said.

"Canada's auction today was moderate to okay, it was nothing stellar. I think you can blame part of that on signals from the U.S. that suggested that their 10 years was not going to go all that well," said Jeoff Hall, Canadian market analyst with Technical Data. "Most of the focus was on the States."
Canada's 30-year bond fell C$0.13 to C$111.92 to yield 7.001 percent.
The U.S. 30-year benchmark bond fell 2/32 to yield 6.71 percent. The spread between the benchmark bonds was 29 basis points, unchanged from Tuesday's close.

The Government of Canada's of C$2.3 billion of 7.25 percent bonds due June 1, 2007 produced and average yield of 6.405 percent. Bids from primary dealers totalled C$5.03 billion, including C$67.05 million of non-competitive tenders at the average yield.
While Canadian auction results were considered respectable analysts said poor demand for the U.S. auction of 10-year notes had a dampening effect on markets in both countries.

The U.S government this afternoon sold US$12 billion in 10-year bonds. Investors there are faced with further supply tomorrow with the final leg of the quarterly refunding, an auction of US$10 billion in 30-year bonds.
In other prices, the Government of Canada's 7.0 percent bond due 2006 fell C$0.09 to C$104.87 to yield 6.323 percent.
The three-month cash T-bill traded with a yield of 2.86 percent against the U.S. bill which yielded 5.14 percent.
